moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bc4 Bc: A slight mistake on white's part here, looking for the knight exchange and forgetting about the e4 pawn.
moves.5... Nxe4 6. d4: White plays this to prevent Nf2.
moves.6... exd4 7. O-O O-O 8. Re1 Nd6 9. Bf4 N: A questionable move by black, since white can trade a bishop for two knights.
If black plays Rxd5, it puts white in a very bad spot. If white comes with Rxe7, then black plays Rd1  . Instead black plays Qf6.
Black can checkmate with Qg2, and if Knight is moved, then with Qh2.
moves.33. Qc8+: Often, players look to constantly check the opposing king under desperation. This move by white actually leads somewhere...
moves.33... Kh7 34. Qf5+ Qg6:
Black has to move Qg6 (queen trade), because if black plays: 34. ... g6, then: 35. Qxf7   Kh8. 36. Re8  
Even so, it goes from potentially losing in one move, to being ahead by a piece for white.
A mistake by black here creates...
